headline: Fettuccine Carbonara
description: This fettuccine carbonara dish is made by cooking bacon, shallots, onion, and garlic, then tossing it with fettuccine pasta and a creamy sauce.
name: Fettuccine Carbonara
recipeIngredient: 1 large onion, cut into thin strips

recipeInstructions.text: Heat olive oil in a large heavy saucepan over medium heat. Sauté shallots until softened. Stir in bacon and onion; cook and stir until bacon is evenly browned. Stir in garlic when bacon is about half done. Remove from heat.
Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add pasta and cook for 8 to 10 minutes or until al dente. Drain pasta, then return it to the pot.
Whisk Parmesan, cream, and egg yolks together in a medium bowl. Pour bacon mixture over pasta; stir in cream mixture. Season with salt and pepper.

Looking at the various photos, I see that many people have not followed the recipe's (somewhat vague) instruction to use bacon "cut into strips." Instead, they've chopped, diced or crumbled the bacon. I've found that when I'm working with long pasta shapes (such as this recipe's fettuccine), it's always best to add other ingredients that have first been cut into similar long, thin shapes, such as by julienning. Such shapes allow the added ingredients to mimic the shape of the pasta, flex & flow with it, cling to it and, effectively, become entrained with it. Short or chunky shapes, on the other hand, just can't behave that way, and will instead tend to fall away from the pasta. (In other recipes that call for chunky pieces of vegetables, use a short pasta shape instead.) So try slicing the long, raw bacon strips into three lengths of approximately equal length. Then cut each of those strips lengthwise (not crosswise) into three fat matchsticks. (And if any of those strips are all or mostly fat, just discard them.) As for the raw egg yolk that's justifiably giving many reviewers pause, I suggest buying pasteurized eggs, if you can find them.
